channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Post-Roe Decision, Abortion Pill Providers Work to Broaden Access
item.description: These new efforts, which test the legal boundaries, have sprung up since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and many states restricted abortion.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Kelly Burgess for The New York Times
item.media:description: New medication abortion services are springing up and existing services are expanding, some adopting new practices that increase access while pushing the envelope of regulations and laws.

item.title: Ukraine Struggles to Identify Bucha Massacre Victims, Five Months On
item.description: No longer able to defer burial, Ukrainian investigators are photographing unclaimed and unidentified bodies, taking DNA samples and assigning them numbers, hoping that one day their families will claim them.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cemetery workers carrying the coffin of an unidentified victim during a funeral last month for 15 people who died in March during the Russian occupation.

item.title: Serena Williams Loses in Three Thrilling Sets to Ajla Tomljanovic
item.description: “It’s been the most incredible ride and journey I’ve ever been on in my life,” Williams, wiping tears, said on court after the match.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams Willed Her Way to a Glorious Goodbye
item.description: Her last match — at the U.S. Open and probably of her career — was a gutsy display of the power and resilience that have kept fans cheering for nearly 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams saved five match points before losing on the sixth at the U.S. Open on Friday. “I don’t give up,” she said. “Definitely wasn’t giving up tonight.”

item.title: Democrats and Republicans Agree That Democracy Is in Danger
item.description: The president seeks to confront threats to American institutions, but Americans are deeply divided on who is imperiling them.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s speech in Philadelphia called on Americans to resist threats to democracy.

item.title: With Midterms Looming, McConnell’s Woes Pile Up
item.description: The minority leader who takes pride in his status as the “grim reaper” of his rivals’ agenda has allowed Democrats to claim policy victories as his party’s hopes of reclaiming the Senate dim.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, and a bloc of Republicans in Congress believe they need to win back suburban voters by supporting issues with broad political appeal.

item.title: Thousands Gather to Pay Final Respects to Mikhail Gorbachev
item.description: At the funeral of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, the size of the crowds signaled the depth of the regret about the undoing of the freedoms that his tenure initiated.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Honor guards standing next to the coffin of Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday at the House of the Unions in Moscow.

item.title: How Shady Ships Use GPS to Evade International Law
item.description: A technology enabling the transmission of fake locations to carry out murky or even illegal business operations could have profound implications for the enforcement of international law.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reliable, left, a ship registered in Cyprus, taking on oil at a refinery in Venezuela. The oil tanker has transmitted fake location coordinates to circumvent international laws and sanctions.

item.title: Judge’s Handling of Surfside Condo Collapse Case Yields Rapid Payout for Victims
item.description: A little over a year after the Champlain Towers South fell, the Surfside condo victims’ families are about to be compensated for their losses.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times

item.title: NASA’s Artemis I Launch to the Moon Scrubbed Again
item.description: Engineers were unable to resolve a hydrogen leak, which led the launch director to call off Saturday’s flight.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Artemis I rocket on the launchpad early Saturday, its second launch attempt.

item.title: Marcus King, a Bluesy Rocker Who Stared Down His Own Crossroads
item.description: The 26-year-old singer and guitarist saw terrifying signs and symbols during the making of his new album, “Young Blood.” He steadied himself, and put it all in the music.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pappademas
item.media:credit: Eric Ryan Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: Republicans Are Showing Contempt for the Rules
item.description: The party is turning against a political commitment to fairness.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Women Are So Fired Up to Vote, I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It
item.description: Since Roe v. Wade was overturned, women have registered to vote in incredible numbers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Bonier
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

item.title: Wonking Out: The Nightmare After Gorbachev
item.description: Why did Russia’s economy do so poorly?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Mark Henley/Panos Pictures, via R​edux

item.title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Less Sexist and Racist. But Is it Good?
item.description: The showrunners say they’ve heard and responded to criticism of ‘Game of Thrones,” but some say that has made the new show boring.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Yang
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Social Mobility
item.description: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
item.dc:creator: John N. Friedman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; the Met Collection; Jordan Graff and Robo Wunderkind, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose and Vacuumfan7072, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: The Post-Colonoscopy Male Friendship Test
item.description: What the pandemic, parenthood and nomadism took away from my life, I replaced with surprisingly intimate connections with other men.
item.dc:creator: Boris Fishman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro. Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Connecting to Nature
item.description: School is for nurturing children’s innate talents and helping them figure out where those gifts, necessarily diverse, fit in the whole.
item.dc:creator: Nicolette Sowder
item.media:credit: Stacy Kranitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolette Sowder home-schools her two daughters and two nieces at her family farm near Cedar Springs, Mich.

item.title: What Is Owed to Pakistan, Now One-Third Underwater
item.description: The Global North can help Pakistan by taking responsibility for the losses and damages of extreme weather fueled in part by the burning of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Bhutto
item.media:credit: Husnain Ali/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flooded residential area in the Dadu district of Sindh Province.

item.title: Game On
item.description: It’s Labor Day weekend, the perfect time to try — you guessed it — pickleball.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: David Sedaris’s Diaries
item.description: The essayist talks about his book “Theft by Finding,” a selection of diary entries spanning 25 years that helped him find and shape his voice as a writer.

item.title: What’s Behind the Pileup of Sex Abuse Scandals?
item.description: Sociologists see a pattern that goes beyond the culture of specific schools, churches and industries: an ingrained resistance to self-policing or defying a community’s hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:credit: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City, Utah.

item.title: A mother-daughter generational divide
item.description: My mom loves cars, but I despise them. Our yearslong debate is a window into the connection between our personal choices and the future of our climate.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni

item.title: Britain’s Pubs Are Threatened by ‘Alarming’ Rise in Energy Bills
item.description: Businesses have fewer protections than residential users against higher electricity and gas costs, and industry groups warn of widespread closings this winter.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pub on Carnaby Street in London. The industry has called for “swift and substantial” government intervention to help pubs deal with energy bills.

item.title: Nine Migrants Drown as Dozens Are Swept Down Rio Grande
item.description: A large group attempting to cross into Texas was overcome by a fast-moving current, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Concertina wire along the Rio Grande in Eagle Pass, Texas.

item.title: Student Loan Forgiveness Is Complicated, Because This Is America
item.description: Instead of making higher education free, we subsidize it later through repayment plans and attempts at debt cancellation. The complexity is disrespectful.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker

item.title: A Volcano Erupted Without Warning. Now, Scientists Know Why.
item.description: A new study explains how Nyiragongo, a volcano in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was relatively quiet before its eruption last year took everyone by surprise.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews
item.media:credit: Alex Miles/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Mount Nyiragongo volcano near Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo, erupting on May 22, 2021.

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
item.description: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: How to Stay Hydrated in a Heat Wave
item.description: Many countries across the globe are facing dangerously high temperatures. Here’s what to do to stay safe.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Jenifer Lewis Is Back on Her Grind With a New Book and ‘I Love That for You’
item.description: With a new Showtime series and book of essays, the veteran actress, who relishes her real-life role as everybody’s auntie, is enjoying her flowers.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus
item.category: I Love That for You (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Juan Veloz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four decades into a showbiz career, high-kicking and scene-stealing are practically muscle memory for Jenifer Lewis.
